titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0342, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Gospel of Matthew bifolium in Latin. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Lat. 68.

msItem.summary: Matthew 10:29-12:1 (lacking, begins with [non]ne duo passers asse veneunt…).
Matthew 13:35-14:22 (lacking, ends with et [statim iussit discipulos ascendere in navicula et praecedere eum trans fretum donec dimitteret turbas].

initials.p: Major initials (20-25 mm) of red or blue with penwork flourishes of the same colors contrasted or combined.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 190 x 135 mm (fol. [1r]). Each column is 190 x 65 mm with a space of 5 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 47 lines. Ruling with hard point.

handDesc.p: Written in textura script in dark brown ink (some fading).

textDivisions.p: Chapter numbers and running titles in red and blue.

origin.p: The manuscript to which the present bifolium belonged is judged to have been written in the 14th century, possibly in Italy.

acquisition.p: Gift of Edgar J. Goodspeed, Professor Emeritus in the Divinity School to the University of Chicago, 1959 or 1960.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.
